body:
There are a lot of special characters in that file and it's not unlikely that one of these causes issues. URxvt also shows similar behavior, however I cannot say why XTerm and VTE do not.

It probably makes sense to investigate a minimal repro case, but generally I don't think it should be a problem. However if there's some reasonable workaround we might as well make use of it.

rename.from: BUG: Terminal print `6c6c6c` into the prompt after executing `cat`
rename.to: Terminal print `6c6c6c` into the prompt after executing `cat`

body:
\033[6c is alacritty's DA response so almost certainly the file contains some sequences of \033[c.

alacritty differs from xterm in that in xterm DA is only responded to if it matches exactly \033[c - parameters aren't allowed, try for example:
~~~~
printf '\033[999c'
~~~~
This class of problems is not very fixable, you can't cat binary data to the terminal and have no risk of something unexpected happening.

Thank you for responses.
You are right, when I try `printf '\033[999c'` it prints `6c`.
I don't really understand, why alacritty differ from other terminals in this matching. Why does it expect parameters?

@Matmaus it doesn't expect them, it just doesn't ignore the sequence if they are present - but it doesn't really matter if it does or not. Don't cat binary files to the terminal. If you must, use cat -v.

Ok, in the case, this is not considered as a bug, I'll close the issue.

But still, `cat -v ` is not a right solution for me.

For example:
**alacritty**:
![2019-11-15-143024_952x140_scrot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31512884/68946897-5c2a3880-07b4-11ea-906d-2c17b6639c5b.png)
VS
**terminator**:
![2019-11-15-143105_953x128_scrot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31512884/68946928-7106cc00-07b4-11ea-9e74-522a31396b36.png)
`cat` without `-v` is much more pretty and readable in my opinion.

The only solution is (for this issue) to use another terminal.

@Matmaus - the point we are trying to make is that you will see funny stuff if you cat binary data to any terminal. Try something like `printf '\033]2;'` in xterm or terminus - the terminal will hang. Your binary data could contain that. If you want to view binary data safely, load it into an editor, or use cat -v, or strings(1), or hexdump/od. Or just live with occasional terminal strangeness :-).
@nicm Thank you for explaining. I have tried it and nothing happened, but I know what do you mean. So thanks, good to know.
